Fields.DialogueText: Algérie, I think the time has come to discuss the ideas you had for improving crew morale.
Oui, Capitaine. And improving their bond, of course.
You're speaking of fraternité, yes?
Oui! We need to bring the crew together.
You think the crew's bond isn't already strong enough?
It isn't that their bond isn't strong already.
Then what do you mean?
Our men would die for each other without question.
So what's the problem?
They need to live for each other as well.

Fields.MenuText: There is such a thing as being too close to one other, you know.
All right, I see your point – heroes live, martyrs die, correct?
I'm not sure I think this is a concern, but I'll trust you on the matter, Algérie.

Fields.DialogueText: They won't be living in each other's pockets or anything, Capitaine.
Unless you're Joan of Arc or Fadhma N'Soumer; they were both in their times.
It isn't a concern so much as an area ripe for improvement.
And you have some ideas as to how to create this bond amongst the crew? Other than constant battles, that is?
Oui, several ideas... but no clue as to which is best or which to attempt first.
Well then, that's something I can help with. Let's start by listing out the...
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
One thing at a time, Capitaine.
Let's get back to this idea of yours, shall we?
Of course. In order to create a proper bonding dynamic, a group of people need a shared goal or experience.
And battle fills that bill, doesn't it?
It does, but that's not what I'm looking for. I want something that will bond the crew together in the good and the bad.
And since battle is bad...
This should be good, oui.

Fields.MenuText: So spit it out already.
I'm on pins and needles here.
You know what happened to the wondering cat, don't you?

Fields.DialogueText: Tsk, tsk... so impatient, dear Capitaine.
And I feel such guilt for your pain. But it will all be worth it in the end.
I have always presumed he went out with a smile.
Be that as it may, your idea?
Oui. It...
... will apparently have to wait.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
All right, quick. Before anything else comes up, tell me your idea.
To lay it out...
Nope, no time for that. Just give it to me quick!
A tea ceremony.
Ha! But seriously, no time for jokes.
Good. It's a tea ceremony.

Fields.MenuText: Hmm... best to rethink that one.
I can't see how this will work.
Wonderful! I've been dying to test out my new frilly hats.

Fields.DialogueText: No need. I've already thought it out.
Don't worry. I'll be your glasses.
I don't think it would necessarily be your style, Capitaine.
Wait, you were serious? Seriously serious?
Is the Pope Catholic?
That's pretty serious.
It will be all right, Capitaine. I have a plan.
Yeah, so do I.
You do? Tell me, what is yours?
Praying.
For what?
For the other shoe not to drop.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
You'll come around. You have before...
Tell me you have something else up your sleeve.
I don't really do sleeves, Capitaine. In either sense.
And you still expect me to go along with this... tea ceremony idea?
What is your objection, Capitaine? The communal drinking of tea is a celebrated tradition in many cultures. What is it you fear?

Fields.MenuText: The fact that not everyone here will understand that tradition.
We're talking about grown adults taking a break from war for sipping tea.
Some people fear spiders, some snakes. I fear full out revolt.

Fields.DialogueText: But I believe they will respect me enough to try, don't you?
Anything sounds terrible when spoken in that tone.
Capitaine, honestly! Your crew adore you.
What does that...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I seem to remember extracting an agreement from you.
Maybe your relaxation therapy got to me.
Well, as long as you're tapping into that tension, there is a battle to be had.
Capitaine, just relax your mind for a few minutes and hear me out.
I'll listen, Algérie, I promise.
You'll listen and not just hear?
What's the difference?
Hearing means the words fall on your ears like seeds fall on desert soil, where they will shrivel and die. Listening means they fall in a furrow where they can blossom and grow.
Very well, Algérie, I will listen.
Do you promise?

Fields.MenuText: Yes, I promise.
I swear it, absolutely.
If that's what it takes, then yes.

Fields.DialogueText: Well then, I think I should thank you... probably.
Thank you, Capitaine!
Your sincerity is somewhat lacking, Capitaine.
Can we just get on with this before...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
If I must set the pace of our discussions, I will.
Was that a warning?
I suppose so. But the cause is just, Capitaine! Just you wait...
The plan itself is simple, Capitaine.
Then it won't take long to lay out.
The ceremony becomes an honor, a tribute to the dead with a focus on the living.
A tribute to the dead?
To the fallen, a remembrance of those who have gone before us so that we may remain here to continue the fight.
We already have funeral ceremonies, Algérie.
But this will not be a funeral, Capitaine. Funerals celebrate the passing to another life. This ceremony will be remembering the fallen to preserve the living.

Fields.MenuText: I'm not sure I see the difference yet.
Am I just dense, or is there more to this?
We celebrate the living by staying alive, don't we?

Fields.DialogueText: I don't see how this is so difficult to understand.
I don't see how this is so difficult to understand.
I don't see how this is so difficult to understand.
Perhaps that's because you're more difficult to kill than the average human.
Is that a hint of jealousy I hear?
Not jealousy, just perspective. Do you understand our perspective on this? Celebrating life by remembering the fallen isn't really the way to go.
You're right... you don't see the difference yet.
Perhaps that's because you're more difficult to kill than the average human.
Is that a hint of jealousy I hear?
Not jealousy, just perspective. Do you understand our perspective on this? Celebrating life by remembering the fallen isn't really the way to go.
I agree... you are just being dense.
Perhaps that's because you're more difficult to kill than the average human.
Is that a hint of jealousy I hear?
Not jealousy, just perspective. Do you understand our perspective on this? Celebrating life by remembering the fallen isn't really the way to go.
We celebrate life however we can, wouldn't you think?
You know, we may need to walk away from this for a bit, let cooler heads return.
Capitaine, I...
No, no... I need a cooler head here. Excuse me.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Then again, maybe I don't.
Capitaine, I apologize if I offended you.
You didn't offend me so much as push a button that I hadn't realized was there. Maybe... and this is a big maybe... but you might have been right with your jealousy push.
Capitaine, I don't think you really are jealous that I'm difficult to kill, per se. I didn't mean it.
But you did say it, which means the thought is there somewhere. It's okay, I understand... I don't like it, but I understand.
Which brings me back to my point about understanding and joining. If we bring the crew together on a subject as difficult as death, imagine how much better they'd work with each other.

Fields.MenuText: Like greasing all the gears?
Like well fitted pipes?
Like beveled joints?

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, nice and greasy, perfect!
Yes, they'd slide right in with each other.
Perfect, tab "A" into slot "B".
What? Did I say something wrong?
No, I think I'm just going to leave that where it is.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
And they say Belles are incomprehensible...
I'm sure you're aware of this, but just to be sure – you know you can't serve tea to the whole crew at one time, don't you?
Of course I do. I plan for every aspect of these things.
I thought so.
I'm going to have the officers do it for me.
Um, say again?
The officers will serve the crew for me.

Fields.MenuText: Nope, I take it back – I'm not sure.
Hmm... I take it back. I think I've missed something.
I take it back completely. You've misunderstood the concept of service.

Fields.DialogueText: No, no, don't take it back, Capitaine. I can explain.
No, no, don't take it back, Capitaine. I can explain.
No, no, don't take it back, Capitaine. I can explain.
Best get on that, then.
Will you still listen?
Best get on that, then.
I can assure you, you've missed nothing except the conclusion.
Best get on that, then.
To serve is to live, Capitaine. This we both understand.
Okay, but about that explanation?
What better way to express the belief of liberté, égalité, fraternité than having the officers serve the crew?
You see, what's bothering me is the part where higher ranking officers serve lower ranking crew.
And that is the problem, Capitaine. We're talking about rank and not station. We are all cut of the same cloth. Just because some of us are higher up on the pole doesn't make us any better.
I... all right, I think that's something I can get behind. You'll have to finish selling me on this later, though. I have an inspection to complete.
Oui, Capitaine. Until later.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Looks like you're not the only one who'll have to wait.
Okay, so explain to me how this will work.
It will be simple. You and the crew come to my tent. I serve tea. We celebrate the life of those around us while honoring those who have passed before us. Simple, no?
No.
I know, no?
No.
Wait, do you mean yes with your no, or no with your no?

Fields.MenuText: I never know what you mean with no.
I don't know anymore what no means.
No.

Fields.DialogueText: You don't know my no?
You're saying you know no more about no?
No?
Now you're just doing it on purpose.
I know, I know, we need to get to the bridge, no?
Yes... wait, no... Forget it. Let's just get to the bridge.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I have a few concerns about your plan, Algérie.
No?
Algérie...
I mean, oui?
Better. You say the officers should come to your tent, but we won't all fit in there. I may not know everything, but I know that much.
Yes, we'll have to extend my tent for that day.
Oh we will, will we?
It's a simple thing, Capitaine. I still have all the supplies we need, don't worry.

Fields.MenuText: Are you going to think about asking permission this time?
And will you be shrinking the tent after this is over?
Sounds like a land grab to me, Algérie.

Fields.DialogueText: I thought I just did.
Oui, of course!
Oh, Capitaine, I'm hurt!
Can you blame me for thinking that way?
Not really, no... but still...
I just realized you haven't explained how you're expanding your tent.
I'm making it bigger and hanging more silk.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Which brings me to my previous question...
Don't think about it too hard, Capitaine. It'll put you off this battle. And your tea.
So how do you expect to pull off an event of this size while we're in the middle of a war?
Everybody docks sometime, Capitaine.
Yes, and the crew and officers look forward to their leave, short as it may be.
This time, it will just be a little shorter than usual.
Wait, you're not thinking I'm going to be the one to deliver this news to them, are you?
Well, an order from the capitaine...
No, absolutely not.
But, Capitaine!

Fields.MenuText: No "but, Captain." You want this done, you'll have to issue the request yourself.
You'll have to make your own requests, Algérie. My command isn't for that.
I'm coming around to the idea, Algérie, but I can't use my authority frivolously.

Fields.DialogueText: All right, fair's fair. I'll issue the requests.
When you're right, you're right. I'll do it myself.
I'll convince them, Capitaine. Just you wait.
I'm glad we have that cleared up. Let me know if you have any issues.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Merci, though I think it will all go smoothly. I've already started expanding the tent space.
...Yes. How exactly were you going about doing that again?
Morganas, Capitaine! We must drop everything and deal with them right away.
Capitaine, do you remember when you said I should let you know if I had any problems telling the crew and officers of my plan? Well... I do.
Oh? Who's giving you grief?
Er, well... truth be told... everyone is.
Everyone? What's happened?
No one has responded to my invitations. I've seen them and I know they've seen the invites, so why won't they respond?
And how did you go about inviting them?
Like I did you. You saw your invitation, didn't you?
No wonder they didn't respond.
Why's that then?

Fields.MenuText: Because they're unnerved.
Because they don't understand.
Because they don't care.

Fields.DialogueText: Why would my invitation unnerve them?
How could they not understand?
What? Why wouldn't they care?
Something you have to understand about the officers and crew is...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
The satchels of herbs on their pillows didn't convince them?
...They can be rather territorial. With Morganas encroaching, it's hard not to be.
It appears I have two projects. Back to it, then.
Tell me, Captain, how do I make my idea work?
I think you need to be a bit more inventive than just sending out mere invitations.
And what would you recommend?
A more personal touch.
What does that mean?

Fields.MenuText: You should hand deliver them.
You should speak with each crew member personally.
Surely you can figure it out on your own.

Fields.DialogueText: Yes, I suppose that might help.
Hmm... speak to them personally? I can see why that might help my cause.
Ah, you mean that I should personalize their invitations. Okay, I understand.
I'm glad that makes sense.
Oui. At least, I have a better idea of what I should try next. Thank you, Capitaine.
Of course, Algérie. Let me know how it works out.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I'll think on this, Capitaine. It makes sense that herbs and spices would not always speak for themselves. You studied hard for that.
And for battle. Let's win one.
I think I've succeeded, Capitaine!
Is that a fact, Algérie?
Your advice worked. The officers and crew are interested in my tea ceremony.
Excellent news! Have you set a date yet?
That's what I wanted to ask you about. As the leader of this ship, you should have a say in the date.
That's very thoughtful of you, Algérie. Now that I say it out loud, I'm not sure having a date set is the best idea.
Why's that? If there's no date, how can people attend?

Fields.MenuText: Because the Morganas always seem to interrupt us at the worst possible time.
Because setting a date only creates anxiety amongst the crew.
Because something like this should be a surprise.

Fields.DialogueText: Point well taken, but how will we get around that?
Won't not knowing create anxiety as well?
For a ceremony during which we're honoring the dead? I suppose you know best...
You're just going to have to trust me on this one, Algérie. I'll figure this part out and let you know when I do.
You'll let me know? So kind of you, Capitaine.
Is that sarcasm I detect, Algérie?
Not in my nature.
*ALARM*
@BATTLE
Sounds suspiciously like something a sarcastic person would say.
That settles it. I'm giving you chamomile after this battle. You're all tense again.
Do you have your things prepared for the ceremony?
How can I when you won't give me the information I need?
It's simple. You gather your supplies together, keep them at the ready, and prepare to make the ceremony happen with thirty minutes' notice.
What part of that was simple?

Fields.MenuText: The part where you do what I tell you.
None of it. I was just trying to soften the blow.
It isn't the easiest task, but it's one you have to work with.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, is that all? Grr... Oui, Capitaine!
Thank you for the attempt.
I will do my best, Capitaine.
Carry on.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
If we can defeat Morganas at a moment's notice, I can make a ceremony happen with several. This might work out after all...
Everything is prepared as you requested, Capitaine.
Excellent. The good news is that we'll be meeting up with a resupply convoy in the next few days. We'll have some other ships to cover us, so we can hold the ceremony then.
That is excellent news. Now we can plan for the...
Hold on, please. I said in the next few days. The actual timing is a bit... sketchy.
Why? Don't they know when they'll be in the area?
Of course they know, but just because they know doesn't mean the enemy has to as well. Think about it. Is that something you want broadcast?
Well... now that you put it like that...

Fields.MenuText: I knew you'd understand.
I'm sorry if that sounded harsh.
Good, I'm glad to see you're on board with me.

Fields.DialogueText: I do. I don't like the whole waiting part, but it is what it is.
It didn't. I mean, my feelings weren't hurt or anything.
I did choose you to be.
I know the situation isn't ideal, Algérie, but these are the circumstances we've been dealt.
I understand, Capitaine. And let me state, for the record - thank you for your help.
@BATTLE
Well, aren't you funny?
*ALARM*
An opportunity to repay you! Let us meet it head on.
So who goes where?
Again? Okay, I'll run you through it. The XO goes here, you go here, I'll be here, the...
@BATTLE
Well now, that was an interesting one.
Interesting how?

Fields.MenuText: Don't misunderstand me, Algérie. I'm just blowing off steam.
Interesting as in I can't let the crew make those kinds of mistakes again.
It's... no offense, it's just not worth explaining.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, now that I understand. Decompress away, Capitaine.
Mistakes? I didn't see many mistakes, Capitaine.
Still can't divulge those innermost thoughts to me, Capitaine?
My mind works in mysterious ways, Algérie. That's just the way it is.
You're not alone on that matter, Capitaine.
Heh... No, I'm not, Algérie. No, I'm not.
*ALARM*
Leave the seating chart, Capitaine.
You're not worried about losing it?
A hit like that and the chart would be the least of our problems.
That is what my invitations were for, incidentally. To show you that you're not alone.
The space is there to share yourself if you feel you need to. You might find that your mind is a little less mysterious if you do.
Thank you, Algérie. I might take you up on that.
Take your time. There is no rush.
Do you have the order down, now?
I believe I do. I'm just not sure how the timing will play out.
In what way?
Well, I know that we'll be steeping different tea combinations for different parts of the ceremony, but just how that happens and in what order it happens still befuddles me.
Oh, don't worry, Capitaine, I'll take care of that.
But you can't be the only one who knows how it works, Algérie.
Why, Capitaine? Do you think something will happen to me?

Fields.MenuText: No, but since the officers will be recreating the ceremony for the crew...
God, no! However, if the officers are to recreate the ceremony for the crew...
Like anything could keep you down! Seriously, though, if the officers are to serve the crew...

Fields.DialogueText: Then they need to know how everything works, of course.
Then they need to know how everything works, of course.
Then they need to know how everything works, of course.
Good. Let's...
@BATTLE
You get it now?
I always did. You forget I plan for everything.
You get it now?
Oui. Don't worry, Captain.
You get it now?
Oui, and we'll be sure they know everything they need to know!
*ALARM*
Patience. We'll fit this in where we can.
Let's get everything ready, Algérie.
Is it happening now?
No, not now, but it's almost here. It being the time, of course.
Of course. Capitaine, is everything all right?
Of course it is. Why do you ask?
You seem a bit - how shall I say - nervous?
Me, nervous? What would I have to be nervous about?
I don't have the slightest idea. Care to fill me in?

Fields.MenuText: I don't know.
Not at the moment.
I'm not quite ready, but when I am, I'll tell you.

Fields.DialogueText: Let me know when you do.
I hope for your sake the moment comes soon.
I look forward to that moment then, Capitaine.
Let's move on. I...
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Hold that thought for me, Capitaine. I will be happy to help you sift through it.
Look, about that thing... I have to admit, I have been holding something in.
And you wish to talk about it now?
Not really, but I have to talk about it to someone.
And I just happen to be close at hand.

Fields.MenuText: You see, you know me so well.
Not at all. I wanted to talk to a friend.
You do know I actually sought you out, right?

Fields.DialogueText: Not as well as I would like, but that can change with time.
A friend? I'm charmed, Capitaine.
My apologies, Capitaine. That couldn't have been easy.
Be that as it may, I...
@BATTLE
Now, about that issue?
Yes, well, it seems I'm more nervous about celebrating the fallen than I thought. Some of the crew... well... other than their service aboard this vessel, I didn't know well at all.
And you're looking for more?
More about who they were as a person, yes.
Don't you see, Capitaine – this is exactly what the ceremony is supposed to be about. The way you feel right now is the way we can all feel. The yearning to know more is why we're gathering.
I understand. At least, I think I do. But... I think I need to think on this more. Excuse me, will you?
Of course, Capitaine.
*ALARM*
I will seek you out the moment our duties are done, Capitaine, and not a second later.
Word from the resupply convoy, Algérie. Any time now.
That's what you said last time.
Things are complicated. The Morganas in the area have made coordinating schedules difficult.
Perhaps I'm the one getting nervous now.
I doubt that, Algérie.
And why is that?

Fields.MenuText: Because you're a Belle. What do you have to be nervous about?
Because you've got this part down cold.
Because tea is your culture. You can't screw up your culture.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm going to take that to mean I'm too excellent to be nervous.
That's sweet, Capitaine. Thank you.
Well said, Capitaine.
Besides, you can't be nervous because that'd make two of us, and that just won't work.
Very well, Capitaine. I'll be confident so you can be nervous.
I very much think that's a joke, Algérie.
And I very much think your speech is strange.
Chalk it up to being nervous.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
But strange or not, it will be understood. That's what I'm here for. That and the war.
Algérie, do you mind if I run parts of my speech past you?
Your tea ceremony speech? You finished it?
That's the one.
I'd be delighted! How does it start?

Fields.MenuText: Ladies and gentlemen, crew of the Algérie...
Friends, crewmen, countrymen, lend me your ear...
In a world gone mad, one thing keeps my hope alive...

Fields.DialogueText: A bit of a weak start, Capitaine, but survivable.
Quoting the Bard, Capitaine? Are you sure that's wise?
Sounds apocalyptic, Capitaine. Shouldn't you go a bit lighter?
I'm not a fan of it either, but I'm at a loss for words. Starting this is just about impossible.
Then don't.
Don't what?
Start the speech.
Algérie, there has to be a start, otherwise there can't be a middle or an end.
What I mean is don't write a speech. Just keep everything in your heart and let it out at the ceremony.
That method will either go excellently or terribly.
Your officers know you well enough by now to know what's real and what's not. Give them what they deserve, Capitaine – words from the heart.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I guess I can't go wrong with that.
Sincerity is not so easy to fake, Capitaine. I will know it is real, and so shall the crew.
As real as a salvo to the face.
Even Morganas must communicate.
All right, Algérie, this is it.
It's time? The convoy is here?
The resupply ship is. As to the rest of the convoy, well, you'll just have to see for yourself.
Wait... that doesn't sound good.
It could be worse.
No, don't say...
What, now?
You had to say it could be worse, didn't you?
@BATTLE
Well, now that that's over, I suggest we gather the officers and crew.
Good idea. Would you like to do it, or shall I?

Fields.MenuText: You should do it. It's your invitation, your ceremony, and your idea.
I don't think it matters. After what we just went through, they'll go anywhere we order them to.
I should do it. It will set the tone for the ceremony.

Fields.DialogueText: And my fault if it goes sour? Just kidding, Capitaine, I'll make it happen.
Then perhaps we should order them to be happy and dust our hands off?
Very well, Capitaine. I look forward to receiving you and the officers at my tent.
Very well, then. Let's go to work.
*ALARM*
Well, I'd have to say that went wonderfully, wouldn't you?
Better than I could have expected, yes.
And the unity? Can you see how it has helped?
You were right about the importance of giving the crew something to live for.
Yet I sense hesitation from you. Anything you wish to pass on, Capitaine?

Fields.MenuText: I'm just not sure how long this feeling will persist.
The experience left me feeling as if each loss will hit much harder going forward.
It seems as if this is something which would benefit the entire fleet... and yet I can't imagine such a practice spreading fleetwide.

Fields.DialogueText: That's our responsibility, Capitaine. If we see the crew's bond faltering, it's up to us to mend the rift.
Which should make you work that much harder to prevent those losses.
Fleets are composed of ships, Capitaine. Things like this happen one at a time.
I suppose you're right.
Oui, but of course I am.
Don't be so humble, Algérie. Let it out.
I always do, Capitaine. I always do.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
I think I might be ready for that talk now.
And it only took the specter of battle to prepare you.
Tea only gets one so far...
I believe I've noticed a change in you, Capitaine.
Oh? And what's that?
Before, when we charged into battle, there was a certain zeal to your eyes. Now, when we charge into battle, the zeal is tinged with caution.
Not too much caution, I hope?
No, nothing that would make you indecisive, only more... aware... of what's happening. I think that's a good thing, Capitaine. I think that's a thing that friends, close friends, would notice.

Fields.MenuText: Close friends, eh? You know, I can live with that.
Close friends? I thought we were crewmates and nothing more.
Close? We work together, Algérie, that's all.

Fields.DialogueText: May our friendship be long and beautiful, Capitaine.
No, I've decided. We're friends now.
Always so gruff, Capitaine. But I think, deep down, you know we're friends.
Awareness is a good way of putting it.
Tell me more.
I tend to focus on minutiae when things get tough. You've seen it when I've pushed you away.
Looking for things you can handle in a world that has spiraled out of control.
Exactly. Maybe it was the ceremony, maybe it was all the tea and spices. But when I think of something falling apart because I look away... well I really don't anymore.
It warms my heart to hear that, Capitaine. I'm glad you can share this with me.
I still need to know how you got all that space. I swear that was a broom closet.
*ALARM*
Now what did we say about details, Capitaine?
Hey, we're not done here, you know.
Bien. I hope we never are.
